In my opinion, there is nothing worse than a cliché character. Too many times have I read a book that seems like the author just read one too many romance novels and decided to copy character profiles. 

The woman in these stories can only wear heels, she is always ready for her hair to be blown around at the slightest sign of wind and she is a virgin. As she has been waiting for love, she also knows that gold diggers and poseurs don't deserve her undying love.

In my opinion, there is nothing worse than a cliché character. Too many times have I read a book that seems like the author just read one too many romance novels and decided to copy character profiles. 

The woman in these stories can only wear heels, she is always ready for her hair to be blown around at the slightest sign of wind and she is a virgin. As she has been waiting for love, she also knows that gold diggers and poseurs don't deserve her undying love. Her long awaited Prince Charming cannot be a gold digger, he must play ball with orphans, and he has to read books too.

In my opinion, there is nothing worse than a cliché character. Too many times have I read a book that seems like the author just read one too many romance novels and decided to copy character profiles. 

The woman in these stories can only wear heels, she is always ready for her hair to be blown around at the slightest sign of wind and she is a virgin. As she has been waiting for love, she also knows that gold diggers and poseurs don't deserve her undying love. 


Her long awaited Prince Charming cannot be a gold digger, he must play ball with orphans, and he has to read books too. The man in these stories is a boss, a millionaire, a hero, he must travel the world and have women fawning over him.

What Stereotypical Characters Make You Cringe?

What stereotypical characters in books, movies or television shows make you cringe and why? Would you ever not watch or read something because of its offensive portrayal of someone?

In my opinion, there is nothing worse than a cliché character. Too many times have I read a book that seems like the author just read one too many romance novels and decided to copy character profiles. 

The woman in these stories can only wear heels, she is always ready for her hair to be blown around at the slightest sign of wind and she is a virgin. As she has been waiting for love, she also knows that gold diggers and poseurs don't deserve her undying love. 


Her long awaited Prince Charming cannot be a gold digger, he must play ball with orphans, and he has to read books too. The man in these stories is a boss, a millionaire, a hero, he must travel the world and have women fawning over him.   He will never think of the woman that holds his heart as an equal, but an object to be worshiped.

In my opinion, there is nothing worse than a cliché character. Too many times have I read a book that seems like the author just read one too many romance novels and decided to copy character profiles. 

The woman in these stories can only wear heels, she is always ready for her hair to be blown around at the slightest sign of wind and she is a virgin. As she has been waiting for love, she also knows that gold diggers and poseurs don't deserve her undying love. 


The man in these stories is a boss, a millionaire, a hero, he must travel the world and have women fawning over him.  Her long awaited Prince Charming cannot be less than movie-star handsome, he must play ball with orphans, and he has to read books too. He will never think of the woman that holds his heart as an equal, but an object to be worshiped.

In my opinion, there is nothing worse than a cliché character. Too many times have I read a book that seems like the author just read one too many romance novels and decided to copy character profiles. 

The woman in these stories can only wear heels, she is always ready for her hair to be blown around at the slightest sign of wind, beautiful as a goddess, naïve and a virgin. As she has been waiting for love, she also knows that gold diggers and poseurs don't deserve her undying love. 


The man in these stories is a boss, a millionaire, a hero, he must travel the world and have women fawning over him.  Her long awaited Prince Charming cannot be less than movie-star handsome, he must play ball with orphans, and he has to read books too. He will never think of the woman that holds his heart as an equal, but an object to be worshiped.


Characters like this need to die already! I want to read stories about women who are college educated--yes, I'm that type of woman, and I know plenty of others who are too.

In my opinion, there is nothing worse than a cliché character. Too many times have I read a book that seems like the author just read one too many romance novels and decided to copy character profiles. 

The woman in these stories can only wear heels, she is always ready for her hair to be blown around at the slightest sign of wind, beautiful as a goddess, naïve and a virgin. As she has been waiting for love, she also knows that gold diggers and poseurs don't deserve her undying love. 


The man in these stories is a boss, a millionaire, a hero, he must travel the world and have women fawning over him.  Her long awaited Prince Charming cannot be less than movie-star handsome, he must play ball with orphans, and he has to read books too. He will never think of the woman that holds his heart as an equal, but an object to be worshiped.


Characters like this need to die already! I want to read stories about women who are college educated--yes, I'm that type of woman, and I know plenty of others who are too. 

I want to read about men who are real--men who have flaws and dreams and those who don't need to be in the spotlight

In my opinion, there is nothing worse than a cliché character. Too many times have I read a book that seems like the author just read one too many romance novels and decided to copy character profiles. 

The woman in these stories can only wear heels, she is always ready for her hair to be blown around at the slightest sign of wind, beautiful as a goddess, naïve and a virgin. As she has been waiting for love, she also knows that gold diggers and poseurs don't deserve her undying love. 


The man in these stories is a boss, a millionaire, a hero, he must travel the world and have women fawning over him.  Her long awaited Prince Charming cannot be less than movie-star handsome, he must play ball with orphans, and he has to read books too. He will never think of the woman that holds his heart as an equal, but an object to be worshiped.


Characters like this need to die already! I want to read stories about women who are college educated--yes, I'm that type of woman, and I know plenty of others who are too. I want to read about men who are real--men who have flaws and dreams and those who don't need to be in the spotlight.

In my opinion, there is nothing worse than a cliché character. Too many times have I read a book that seems like the author just read one too many romance novels and decided to copy character profiles. 

The woman in these stories can only wear heels, she is always ready for her hair to be blown around at the slightest sign of wind, beautiful as a goddess, naïve and a virgin. As she has been waiting for love, she also knows that gold diggers and poseurs don't deserve her undying love. 


The man in these stories is a boss, a millionaire, a hero, he must travel the world and have women fawning over him.  Her long awaited Prince Charming cannot be less than movie-star handsome, he must play ball with orphans, and he has to read books too. He will never think of the woman that holds his heart as an equal, but an object to be worshiped.


Characters like this need to die already! I want to read stories about women who are college educated--yes, I'm that type of woman, and I know plenty of others who are too. I want to read about men who are real--men who have flaws and dreams and those who don't need to be in the spotlight. 

Characters like that aren't perfect, but they are real... and they can still have love in their lives.

In my opinion, there is nothing worse than reading about a cliché character. Too many times have I read a book that seems like the author just read one too many romance novels and decided to copy character profiles. 

The woman in these stories can only wear heels, she is always ready for her hair to be blown around at the slightest sign of wind, beautiful as a goddess, naïve and a virgin. As she has been waiting for love, she also knows that gold diggers and poseurs don't deserve her undying love. 


The man in these stories is a boss, a millionaire, a hero, he must travel the world and have women fawning over him.  Her long awaited Prince Charming cannot be less than movie-star handsome, he must play ball with orphans, and he has to read books too. He will never think of the woman that holds his heart as an equal, but an object to be worshiped.


Characters like this need to die already! I want to read stories about women who are college educated--yes, I'm that type of woman, and I know plenty of others who are too. I want to read about men who are real--men who have flaws and dreams and those who don't need to be in the spotlight. Characters like that aren't perfect, but they are real... and they can still have love in their lives.

In my opinion, there is nothing worse than reading about a cliché character. Too many times have I read a book that seems like the author just read one too many romance novels and decided to copy character profiles. 

The woman in these stories can only wear heels, she is always ready for her hair to be blown around at the slightest sign of wind, beautiful as a goddess, naïve and a virgin. As she has been waiting for love, she also knows that gold diggers and poseurs don't deserve her undying love. 


The man in these stories is a boss, a millionaire, a hero, he must travel the world and have women fawning over him.  Her long awaited Prince Charming cannot be less than movie-star handsome, he must play ball with orphans, and he has to read books too. He will never think of the woman that holds his heart as an equal, but an object to be worshiped.


Characters like this need to die already! I want to read stories about women who are college educated--yes, I'm that type of woman, and I know plenty of others who are too. I want to read about men who are real--men who have flaws and dreams and those who don't need to be in the spotlight. Characters like that aren't perfect, but they are real... and they can still have love in their lives. 


I'm personally not a fan of stories that are nothing but an instructional manual on how to be a woman, and how to be a man, but I know that there are people who enjoy these stories.

In my opinion, there is nothing worse than reading about a cliché character. Too many times have I read a book that seems like the author just read one too many romance novels and decided to copy character profiles. 

The woman in these stories can only wear heels, she is always ready for her hair to be blown around at the slightest sign of wind, beautiful as a goddess, naïve and a virgin. As she has been waiting for love, she also knows that gold diggers and poseurs don't deserve her undying love. 


The man in these stories is a boss, a millionaire, a hero, he must travel the world and have women fawning over him.  Her long awaited Prince Charming cannot be less than movie-star handsome, he must play ball with orphans, and he has to read books too. He will never think of the woman that holds his heart as an equal, but an object to be worshiped.


Characters like this need to die already! I want to read stories about women who are college educated--yes, I'm that type of woman, and I know plenty of others who are too. In my opinion, there is nothing worse than reading about a cliché character. Too many times have I read a book that seems like the author just read one too many romance novels and decided to copy character profiles. 

The woman in these stories can only wear heels, she is always ready for her hair to be blown around at the slightest sign of wind, beautiful as a goddess, naïve and a virgin. As she has been waiting for love, she also knows that gold diggers and poseurs don't deserve her undying love. 


The man in these stories is a boss, a millionaire, a hero, he must travel the world and have women fawning over him.  Her long awaited Prince Charming cannot be less than movie-star handsome, he must play ball with orphans, and he has to read books too. He will never think of the woman that holds his heart as an equal, but an object to be worshiped.


Characters like this need to die already! I want to read stories about women who are college educated--yes, I'm that type of woman, and I know plenty of others who are too. I want to read about men who are real--men who have flaws and dreams and those who don't need to be in the spotlight. Characters like that aren't perfect, but they are real... and they can still have love in their lives. 

I won't read books or watch television with such lazy writing. It isn't healthy, and I'm tired of it. The media is changing around us, and we can't be content with the same old stereotypes that are demeaning and dehumanizing.

What Stereotypical Characters Make You Cringe?

What stereotypical characters in books, movies or television shows make you cringe and why? Would you ever not watch or read something because of its offensive portrayal of someone?

---

In my opinion, there is nothing worse than reading about a cliché character. Too many times have I read a book that seems like the author just read one too many romance novels and decided to copy character profiles. 

The woman in these stories can only wear heels, she is always ready for her hair to be blown around at the slightest sign of wind, beautiful as a goddess, naïve and a virgin. As she has been waiting for love, she also knows that gold diggers and poseurs don't deserve her undying love. 


The man in these stories is a boss, a millionaire, a hero, he must travel the world and have women fawning over him.  Her long awaited Prince Charming cannot be less than movie-star handsome, he must play ball with orphans, and he has to read books too. He will never think of the woman that holds his heart as an equal, but an object to be worshiped.


Characters like this need to die already! I want to read stories about women who are college educated--yes, I'm that type of woman, and I know plenty of others who are too. I want to read about men who are real--men who have flaws and dreams and those who don't need to be in the spotlight. Characters like that aren't perfect, but they are real... and they can still have love in their lives. 

I won't read books or watch television with such lazy writing. It isn't healthy, and I'm tired of it. The media is changing around us, and we can't be content with the same old stereotypes that are demeaning and dehumanizing. Let's celebrate the strengths of those who are 'different' and let's laugh at the ones who think they're above us. If we kick them in the shins, they'll have to find a new pair of shoes...

What stereotypical characters in books, movies or television shows make you cringe and why? Would you ever not watch or read something because of its offensive portrayal of someone?

In my opinion, there is nothing worse than reading about a cliché character. Too many times have I read a book that seems like the author just read one too many romance novels and decided to copy character profiles. 

The woman in these stories can only wear heels, she is always ready for her hair to be blown around at the slightest sign of wind, beautiful as a goddess, naïve and a virgin. As she has been waiting for love, she also knows that gold diggers and poseurs don't deserve her undying love. 


The man in these stories is a boss, a millionaire, a hero, he must travel the world and have women fawning over him.  Her long awaited Prince Charming cannot be less than movie-star handsome, he must play ball with orphans, and he has to read books too. He will never think of the woman that holds his heart as an equal, but an object to be worshiped.


Characters like this need to die already! I want to read stories about women who are college educated--yes, I'm that type of woman, and I know plenty of others who are too. I want to read about men who are real--men who have flaws and dreams and those who don't need to be in the spotlight. Characters like that aren't perfect, but they are real... and they can still have love in their lives. 

I won't read books or watch television with such lazy writing. It isn't healthy, and I'm tired of it. I don't want my daughters to grow up with such unrealistic perceptions of love and dating. The media is changing around us, and we can't be content with the same old stereotypes that are demeaning and dehumanizing. Let's celebrate the strengths of those who are 'different' and let's laugh at the ones who think they're above us.

In my opinion, there is nothing worse than reading about a cliché character. Too many times have I read a book that seems like the author just read one too many romance novels and decided to copy character profiles. 

The woman in these stories can only wear heels, she is always ready for her hair to be blown around at the slightest sign of wind, beautiful as a goddess, naïve and a virgin. As she has been waiting for love, she also knows that gold diggers and poseurs don't deserve her undying love. 


The man in these stories is a boss, a millionaire, a hero, he must travel the world and have women fawning over him.  Her long awaited Prince Charming cannot be less than movie-star handsome, he must play ball with orphans, and he has to read books too. He will never think of the woman that holds his heart as an equal, but an object to be worshiped.


Characters like this need to die already! I want to read stories about women who are college educated--yes, I'm that type of woman, and I know plenty of others who are too. I want to read about men who are real--men who have flaws and dreams and those who don't need to be in the spotlight. Characters like that aren't perfect, but they are real... and they can still have love in their lives. 

I won't read books or watch television with such lazy writing. It isn't healthy, and I'm tired of it. I don't want my daughters to grow up with such unrealistic perceptions of love and dating. The media is changing around us, and we can't be content with the same old stereotypes that are demeaning and dehumanizing. Let's celebrate the strengths of those who are 'different' and let's laugh at the ones who think they're above us. Let's read and write and watch stories that show what it's really like.
